entry.title: My Sapphire Orlando 2025 recap from an SAP Community point of view
entry.content:
Hi everybody!  Mr. bluebeard here and I wanted to give you a recap of my experience at this year's SAP Sapphire 2025 event in Orlando, Florida. 

The Show Floor

When I got to Orlando, it was a lot like coming home because I've been to several Sapphires but there's nothing like that feeling when you approach the Orange County Convention Center and you know that you're about to go through an amazing entranceway and see a beautiful show floor.  Well, that's what happened.  The SAP team designed an amazing show entrance that was very photo worthy.  The show floor had lots of vendor and partner booths to the left, and a keynote stage auditorium to the right as well as a broadcast studio for virtual attendee presentations.  Along the sides we several large and small theaters for dedicated deep dive presentations, and a meeting center in the back.  There were several areas to relax and take phone calls as well, but most amazing to me was the center hallway of the show floor.

entrance before escalator down show floor main walkway

The center hallway started off with the SAP Experience Center, which I'm part of in Team SIX (Solution, Industries and Experience), the SIX team is responsible for designing and giving people a great experience going through all the innovations that SAP software is enabling. For this Experience Center you queued up outside like you were waiting at an amusement park and then you enter and you are informed about the persona journey that you're about to partake in, much like you would at an SAP Experience Center at an SAP office.  You pick a role like CEO, CPO, CHRO, then you get a AirTag that syncs to an Android or an iPhone so you can browse all the learnings on your mobile if you didn't have time to complete everything in the Experience Center.  They brought in a industrial injection machine, a warehouse robot set up to show how you could repair that equipment if it broke using AI. Once you get done in the experience center and you exit the enclosed area you're in the center hallway again.  You see a lot of beautiful booths with experts from BTP, Applications and a lot of people that are just having conversations with our customers and partners about SAP technology.

experience center experience center guided tourairtag delivery robot arm

Then when you reach the back edge of the hallway before you get to the meeting event center that's where you see the great Learning and Certification Lab. We had a 25 person auditorium theater built into it, several different touch panels where you could choose to take a picture of yourself and have AI generate a graphic image of you tied to your user name. After completing quizzes your image & name were listed on a leaderboard for all to see.  But also as you tapped your badge at the monitors and completed knowledge exercises you accumulated learning power and the tree of learning would glow brighter the more you learned. 

Andre Bechtold preso in Lab leaderboardLearning and Certification Lab Sitting area outside labtree of learning

Now onto what I did while in the space.  In the theater at the back of the Learning and Certification Lab is where myself and one of our SAP mentors @DanielleLarocca, as well as @anita_riegel from team SIX all got together and presented in a panel format "How to Harness the Power of the SAP Community".  It was a 25 minute chat to explain to people what the SAP community is and how they can benefit from it because it's their community.  Everyone who was sitting in that room was a member of the community just by being there.  Maybe they don't use the website, so we directed them to community.sap.com and how they can use those resources once signed up, but also being present at Sapphire, SAP TechEd, SAP Inside Tracks, Meetups and attending things like an an SAP CodeJam allow for community interaction in person, around the world.

 

Also I just met and talked with people outside of the SAP learning certification lab when I wasn't in a meeting.  Speaking of meetings, a lot of my time was spent working with people that are part of the SAP Mentors and Champions programs, enjoying conversations with them about what we can do to make our community experiences better.  They met with SAP executives and leaders within several SAP organizations and expressed direct feedback, so it was very nice to be a part of those meetings along with @StephanieMarley 

Then I went to a meeting with the SAP AppHaus team, and learned more about their network of SAP AppHaus locations and what they're doing with the partner network to expand the reach of the AppHaus methodology and how we can host things like a CodeJam, or do other customer events inside of these AppHaus locations which are optimized to take people through the SAP AppHaus methodology for solving their business problems.

AppHaus meeting

My Favorite Moment

I met a lot of new friends as well at after hours events like the AWS Networking Session. One was a gentleman from Mexico, Adrian, who works for a lighting industry company.   It was honestly my favorite moment because I got to hear his story about what it was like to attend Sapphire in Philadelphia (where i live) in 1996 as well as SAP TechEd that year, so really cool stories comparing not only those early events but the changes to the software we are presenting now that his company utilizes.  Adrian has been around for a long time and he has seen the change of SAP software as well as the differences between on premise and cloud, and now the integration of AI and how businesses utilize that software. 

The Keynotes

The keynotes were great from a high level. I attended all the keynote sessions at the keynote theater, which is a large space on the show floor that was full, even into the stadium seating outside.  Seeing all the great presentations with the things that we're doing from all the executives was awesome, but seeing a friend of mine, Abishek, from the old SAP mobile team who is now moved through his career up to the point where he's working for NBC Universal and was one of the customers on stage presenting how they are using all these great things was so fun and rewarding to see. 

A few of the announcements from the keynotes:

  • Intelligent Apps for the SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Joule AI assistant availability
  • Perplexity partnership
  • AI Foundation
  • many more.... 

keynote selfie Thomas Saueressig at keynoteoverflow seating

 

Celebration Night

Then we had a great event at Disney's Epcot Center Park where SAP entertained everyone who came to Sapphire by renting out the entire park.  We had two opportunities to listen to some music from the concert artist, The Zac Brown Band, and just if you wanted to ride rides or enter into any of the different country themed sections of Epcot Park you could do that.  There were several places to grab food, snacks, drinks, and just talk to all your friends and colleagues from SAP.   It was a nice night, but a little humid as Florida tends to be. I made it halfway around the world...

Epcot entrance Zac Brown

Epcot at night

‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ

In Summary

Finally flying home after a long week of meetings and having great interactions with all the people on the show floor reminds me it is such an honor to get to do what I do.  As I like to say, I have a "get to job".  I get to do this!  And I enjoyed reflecting by looking at the tons of pictures that I took, especially for the Selfies with bluebeard post, Well over 30 people commented on my beard which was so great cause I used that as an ice breaker to get a pic.  I know @moshenaveh has asked other people attending Sapphire to write up their experiences from this year's Sapphire and I look forward to reading those recaps. 

It was a certifiably good time.  Hope to see you at the next event.

who, what, where?!?

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: Encontro SAP - Let's talk about Joule (meetup)
entry.content:
The local SAP Community in S√£o Paulo has a chance to meet after our SAP CodeJam and the night before the S√£o Paulo SIT!

Encontro SAP in S√£o Paulo will happen on July 25th, 2025 at 18:00 local time for a few hours, so join us and be a part of our Group!  You don't have to be an attendee of our SAP CodeJam event or the SIT, just someone active or curious about the SAP Community and our focus on #developers and technical conversations.

Let‚Äôs talk about what's new in the SAP world, about interesting SAP projects in the region, and what's new with ourselves.

Please let us know if you will participate in SAP Stammtisch by clicking "I will attend", the location is a restaurant called Soul Botequim.  FYI, everyone is responsible for their own to buy a food/drink item if they wish, we are just happy for the chance to connect in person and have some relaxing conversation!

Click here to find more information about the SAP Developer Advocates Latin America Roadshow

entry.title: SAP Stammtisch Dresden - Let's Talk about Joule!
entry.content:
The local SAP Community in Dresden has a chance to meet and discuss whatever is on your mind about SAP Joule, Business Data Cloud, any technical topics like CAP, RAP, just whatever is on you mind.  Your host will be @josh_bentley so come meet, take a pic, or just share some stories with Josh as this is his first time in Dresden!

SAP Stammtisch in Dresden will happen on June 17th, 2025 at 18:00 local time for a few hours, so join us and be a part of our Group!  You don't have to be an attendee of any other local SAP event, just someone active or curious about the SAP Community and our focus on developers and technical conversations.

Let‚Äôs talk about what's new in the SAP world, about interesting SAP projects in the region, and what's new with ourselves.

Please let us know if you will participate in this SAP Stammtisch by clicking "I will attend", the location is a restaurant called Watzke am Goldenen Reiter  in downtown Dresden near the Golden Reiter statue.  Be sure to bring a jacket in case there isn't enough room inside for our group.

FYI, everyone is responsible for their own cost to buy a food/drink item if they wish, we are just happy for the chance to connect in person and have some relaxing conversation!

entry.content: Cannot be more excited to see everyone online and in person!!!  And @TammyPowlas let's make a local event happen in our mid-atlantic area, even if just a meetup with drinks!

entry.title: SAP CodeJam Roadshow LATAM - 2025, the First Half Recap, Being Present is About More Than Words.
entry.content:
Being present, is about more than words

So a few months ago back in April  I was chatting with my developer advocate colleague @ajmaradiaga about my new role as a Community Advocate and doing more outreach.  Attending more events in person specifically, and one type of event that we need to be present at is the SAP Inside Track (SIT's) and I was invited by the amazing team in Brazil that runs so many SIT events in Brazil. In particular I was asked to attend, and then asked to speak, and then speak twice, at the SIT in S√£o Paulo.  The goal of this outreach was to have our team of Community Advocates be more present and listen and talk in person more, and not just online.  In talking about this plan with Developer Advocate Antonio Maradiaga he had a thought.   After the success of last years LATAM roadshow (that he and I did)  he said since he was going to do it again this year with a goal to visit a few cities they hadn't been to, Lima Peru and Mexico city, and also a repeat visit in Bogota.  But since I was going to be in S√£o Paulo on a Saturday for the SIT and the encontro the day before (Antonio helped organize a local meetup called an encontro and @RobertaFernande picked a great spot) maybe I could host a #CodeJam there and then meet him and @RichHeilman the next week in Lima.  Of course I agreed and the plan was set to use the SAP office and have a GenAI CodeJam in S√£o Paulo.

Being present, again and unintended effects:

Fast forward to SAP Sapphire in Orlando. I‚Äôm giving a presentation on community and also attending meetings with the SAP Mentors. In one meeting I‚Äôm next to @ChrisRae  and he says ‚Äúmate, gotta head to an #Apphaus meeting, can you join?"

I say sure and follow him over.  Then when I walk in, I‚Äôm amazed to see a lot of faces in person that I‚Äôd been emailing with about growing the SAP Community presence at the Apphaus locations.  I say a few words and talk about how the team of Developer Advocates can host a CodeJam or I can have meetings at their space if they are willing to host.  All of the partners love this idea. Then a person came up at the end of the meeting named Renan Guedes. He said he runs the Apphaus in S√£o Paulo and wanted me to visit when I was there. I said hey, why don‚Äôt I ask Antonio to move the CodeJam from our office to the Apphaus.

Apphaus meetinFirst time meeting Renan

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Pretty cool!  First half of the LATAM roadshow 2025 is set. 

  • CodeJam at the exec consulting Apphaus
  • Meetup at bar 
  • SIT S√£o Paulo at the campus of PUC 
  • Then off to Lima for the next CodeJam and a quedada (meetup in espa√±ol)
  • Bonus, I got a coffee with SAP Mentor @Raquel_PereiradaCunha me and Raquel

Being present, the reality

I land in Brazil. My colleague @SavioMarques  agrees to pick me up and we can go to get a coffee then attend get to the CodeJam and setup early. Savio showing me the best coffee!

It‚Äôs a great space and the team at Exed Consulting are so gracious. They welcome our local attendees and we are off showcasing how to sue GenAI in BTP. I have great conversations in English as my Portuguese is, lacking. We even did a podcast!

Apphaus group photo

CodeJam in action

Then after we have gone through our 5-6 hours of content we break for day. I‚Äôm hopeful to see a few of the attendees at the meetup along with some of the SIT attendees who are already in town.  I‚Äôm blown away. We get about 25 people. Several form the CodeJams and several sit.  A few SAP Champions are there like @Marssel700 and I even get a present for the next day, a couple of shirts, SIT shirts. One even has my name.

SIT Shirts

 

encontro S√£o Paulo

I‚Äôm not too tired but want to make sure I‚Äôm able to get some rest and prepare for my two sessions and also have great conversations so I head back to the hotel, which for some reason has blue stains on the pillow case?

I called this section ‚Äúbeing present, the reality‚Äù but I had no idea just how many great conversations I would have. How many photos I would take with the attendees. Roberta  even made a Brazilian flat Josh!!!

Brazilian flat Josh, also taller than me

 

I give my presentation on the technical side of the conference. I have a great lunch with a few locals and then my colleague Savio makes sure I meetup with a new colleague I met at the CodeJams named Arthur who agrees to make sure if I need anything he‚Äôs there to help.  Everyone is so kind.  For those interested in a photo but don't want a 1-1 we meet at the court for a group photo!

‚ÄÉ

My second presentation is great and the audience is very happy when I end with a slide stating ‚ÄúVai Conrinthians!‚Äù and the logo of the local favorite football team (soccer to me‚Ä¶), that was my loudest applause and cheers of the day!

Group selfie at SIT S√£o Paulo

 

We have a wrap up meal with several of the SIT organizers and then the next I'm off to Lima Peru where there are two code jams and a meetup Called a quedada locally.  Me and the crew meet in the hotel lobby to strategize!

 

gotta be on the blue crue!

 The first of two CodeJam's is on ABAP so Rich takes the lead showing how to use Joule with ABAP code and prompting the system to give contextual responses based on the functions you put into your ABAP code.  The group in Lima is loving it and the exercises fly by as they consume code they know but in a new way.  ABAP CodeJam Lima

 

quedada Lima

I won‚Äôt be able to stay for the second CodeJam due to my travel schedule, but that‚Äôs ok cause I am sure the Lima attendees are in good hands with Antonio and Rich.  I even heard that most of the GenAI content on day 2 was translated on the fly to espa√±ol by Antonio. 

My favorite memory of the CodeJam and quedada was what I usually say about every event, the people.  Conversations about music, food, life.  The amount of time some attendees took to travel to be with us is staggering and so overwhelming.  Being present really does something for me that I am not sure the attendees of our community event‚Äôs realize. It‚Äôs not about what we discuss, what they learn, what product issue we may solve.  It‚Äôs the connection, the memories made together that are chapters in this amazing virtual novel I'm writing, event by event, called ‚ÄúMy SAP Community journey‚Äù.  I hope you can all be present with us in some way and write your own stories.  Obrigado, gracias and thank you!

Oh, I almost forgot, Antonio made some world tour shirts!

Roadshow tour shirts by Antonio

 roadshow shirt close up

 

Now, for the second half of the LATAM roadshow I will hand over to my colleague @ajmaradiaga to let us know how things go in Mexico City and Bogota!

p.s. I am so sorry to all I can't post all the selfie pics and your name here, but maybe you can post the one's you took as a reply???

entry.title: Story Time - The letters "D" and "K"
entry.content:
Hey, everybody. I'm here today in the Newtown Square Library, and I want to share something with you in story time mode. Today's story is going to focus on two letters, the letters D and K. Now, those letters might make you think of a band or maybe a fashion icon, but for me, they connect to something different.

Back in June, I was lucky enough to get to go to our SAP developer meeting in Dresden, Germany, and then I also went to the one in Mannheim. While I was in Dresden, I met someone who rocks blue hair like me. Her name is Doreen Kaestner. here is a photo of me and Doreen.

And she gave me something. This bracelet. I'm not a Swifty, but I have a friendship bracelet now from Doreen from Dresden, and it says SAP Dresden on it. And I've worn it ever since. The only time I take it off is when I touch up my beard, which I need to do this weekend. But I don't want to get blue hair dye all over the bracelet. So that's the only time I take it off. Otherwise, it stays on. And it's not just about Dresden and Doreen. It's a reminder of the entire SAP community, the family I'm proud to be a part of.

 

So fast forward a few weeks. I'm down in the LATAM Roadshow in South America. I do a few events in Brazil and Lima, Peru. And then I go home because it's time for vacation. And I found myself with my family in Stockholm, Sweden. Out of nowhere, in old city near the water, someone shouts, Hey, I know you! You're from SAP. And I was like, yeah. I shook his hand and I said, hey, what's your name? He said, I'm Dorian Kaucher, DK, another DK, just like Doreen. Dorian works in a small office in southern Germany called Markdorf and focuses on sustainability initiatives. And when I asked if I could take a picture with him, he said, well, I need one, too, because I want to show all my colleagues back in the office that I met you.

 Honestly it's it's crazy because you all make me so much better by being a part of this SAP community by showing up and by connecting but it's so flattering right the energy i get from being able to be recognized is awesome and i appreciate that but i wish i could remember all your names and all your initials when i meet you but these moments they matter they matter to me so know that i do keep them inside they really do matter so from Dresden to Stockholm June to August, all the way through the year, all the way through Latin America, all the time. I'm thinking about you and you give me so much energy. And I love being a part of this SAP community because of that and because of you. So I invite you, though, that if you need something, I can help you connect to other people. So for Dorian, if you want to connect with him and talk about sustainability initiatives and all the great work him and his team are doing down in Markdorf, let me know. And if you need help from Doreen with some development, she's over in Dresden and if she can't help you with her SAP skills, maybe somebody else on the team can, she'll help connect you. I love being a connector, and other people can then connect others from that. So it's a great thing being a part of this SAP community, online and in person.

And speaking of online, Devtoberfest starts the last week of September. So I hope you're registered, and we'll see you online for that for four weeks. And then on November 4th, we're going to be online and in person for SAP TechEd. We're going to be in Berlin November 4th through 6th as well as Louisville, KY the same dates with an on tour stop, and then some of us go the next week to Sydney, Australia and after that a couple weeks later we're in Bengaluru, India.

So I promise with all of this happening I'll have more stories for you very soon. Thank you for reading, bye.

entry.title: Re: The Unofficial SAP Community HTML Tags Documentation
entry.content:
Hi all of my fellow SAP Community members!  Always love your passion and commitment to raising the conversation up and being as constructive and helpful as possible with your post, and your comment replies for all members new & old to our online platform to see and learn from. 

To that end I wanted to thank Marian for this post as it gives me and the very hard working team behind the scenes a chance to engage and give you a short status update on this topic of HTML tags.  Please see the attached table below and know that we are working on an approach to enable additional tags.  - Josh

 

Current permissions:
 
HTML Tag
Allowed HTML Tag Attributes
Description
<a>
href, target
Creates a hyperlink
<b>
none
Bold
<blockquote>
dir
Creates an indented block of text
<br>
none
Line break
<center>
none
Centers text
<div>
align, class
Surrounds a block of content to be formatted together
<em>
none
Italicize
<font>
face, size, color
Controls font size, face and color
<hr>
none
Horizontal line
<i>
none
Italics
<li>
none
List items (used with <ol> or <ul>)
<ol>
 
Ordered list
<p>
align
A paragraph of text
<pre>
none
Pre-formatted text. Typically using a monospace font
<span>
class
Groups text to be formatted together
<strike>
none
Strikethrough
<strong>
none
Bold
<table>

cellspacing, cellpadding, border, width, height

Table
<td>
width, height
Table column
<tr>
width, height
Table row
<u>
none
Underline
<ul>
 
Unordered list
